On Apr 28, 2007, at 3:53 PM, afcarl2 wrote:

> The attractiveness of evolving
> global relationships in the Hypercube network is self-apparent, but
> the set of useful problems in which the substrate network made up of
> only input and output nodes seems limiting.

Right.  With HyperNEAT, I assumed that you would (manually, a priori)  
locate hidden nodes on the substrate.  And, yes, some evolutionary  
mechanism needs to be devised so that substrate configurations may  
also be evolved.  Ken seemed to agree, and I wonder if they're  
already working on this?

With or without that mechanism, adding evolvability of activation  
functions feels complex to me... in the sense that it's probably  
unnecessary.  But, I don't know, it's just a feeling.  If you  
formally compare with and without activation evolution, I'd certainly  
like to see the results.

Now, in your case, if you're not putting any hidden nodes on the  
substrate, I can see how this would help; however, I wonder if it's  
enough?  Just doesn't seem like you're going to get very far without  
using hidden nodes.

--Steve
--Apple-Mail-3--212100577
